Speaking in the Parliament on Friday night on the Increase In BorrowingTreasury Notes Act, Imbert questioned what was being put in place to assist people who lived off their savings and are being destroyed by the low interest rates. He said Minister of Finance Larry Howai was looking at an economic boom in the future but the present situation was very important as well. I am talking about now, when people cannot survive on $500 and $1,000 interest on their savings when in the past they were getting $5,000 and $6,000 a month, they could survive. That is the kind of monetary and fiscal policy I would like to hear brought to this House. Policies from the government to deal with decent incomes for retirees and people who live on savings, Mr Speaker, and how the Central Bank can work with the Ministry of Finance on a fiscal and monetary policy to assist the people who have fixed incomes in this country, he said. Imbert added that he saw no reason for the current Act before the Parliament, adding that the Minister of Finance had not explained what advice he has gotten from the Central Bank on it. We cannot support this, we see no need for this, we call on the minister to forget this and bring a motion to this House discussing the economy of Trinidad and Tobago, the problem of under-employment in Trinidad and Tobago, the problem of increasing transfers and subsidies, the weakness of the economy, the anaemia that is inherent in our financial system and the problems of people who are on fixed saving are struggling everyday with their meagre savings and their anaemic returns on their investments how are they going to live that is what I want to discuss, he said. Minister of Education Dr Tim Gopeesingh, who spoke directly after Imbert, argued that the Government cannot interfere with the monetary policies of the Governor of the Central Bank but they are in sync with the Central Bank which has maintained an accommodative monitoring policy stance. He said: We are indeed very concerned about the plight of our senior citizens whose lifelong earnings are put into banks and right now they cannot get the type of interest rates that they can live off these interest rates. We are very concerned about that, Mr Speaker, and we are very concerned about the lending rate and the deposit rate. And we have a responsible Minister of Finance who I am sure is going to address that with the Central Bank Governor and look at the spread between the lending rate and the borrowing rate and hes going to work to ensure that the interest rates for some of our senior citizens who have some fixed deposits and living off that will be addressed. In 2013, we project overall Gross Domestic Product growth of about one-and-a-half per cent the non-energy sector should register growth of 2.5 per cent. The Central Bank Governor has asked that Ministry of Finance effect resolutions so that we can have more borrowings for the treasury notes and the T Bills. Gopeesingh added that the Central Bank review conducted for 2013 shows the positive fiscal effects for 2013 include overall increase in growth in the economy, and that it was expected it to increase by 1.6 per cent in 2013 in comparison to the 1.2 per cent in 2012 with an overall growth of 2.5 per cent in the non-petroleum sector. He said for the first time the country is experiencing a 2.5 per cent growth in the non-petroleum sector and a growth in the energy sector of 45 per cent. And according to the World Economic Forum Global Competitiveness Report 2013, Trinidad and Tobago is now in the category of innovation-driven economies among the most developed group of countries in the world. This comes on the heels of the countrys graduation to developed country status. The OECD has classified us as graduating to developed-country status. Mendel, a human rights lawyer and head of the Centre for Law and Democracy, a Canada-based international human rights NGO, stressed that senior political figures should seek to distance themselves not only from media business interests but all business interests. \"They sit in Cabinet, they're in a position to influence all of the main policies and directions of the country which would impact on their businesses and that puts them in a potential conflict of interest,\" he said. Mendel continued: \"And ideally they should actually put their businesses at arms length to themselves...before they go into politics and they shouldn't actively pursue businesses that they may be able to privilege through their policy making powers.\" Mendel stressed that the case was \"four times stronger\" for media businesses as they are central to the democratic process. He said it would be difficult to design rules to regulate this issue but \"probably it was more about making politicians pay at the ballot box for their behaviour\". Mendel noted, however, that by buying the media they then affect the way the ballot box works. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/amnestys-swipe-at-obama-over-human-rights-hypocrisy/article_b2daab2a-85c2-5d7f-a8af-ecf329abcc28.html", "TITLE": " Amnestys swipe at Obama over human rights hypocrisy ", "DATE": "Jan 24, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "United States President Barack Obama may have to cease speaking with a forked tongue on the continuing misuse of the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base as a detention centre for political prisoners from other countries and also wake up and smell the \"political coffee\" over the spreading and deepening relations with Cuba by hemispheric governments and international organisations. As the government in Havana was completing arrangements to host this week's second summit of the Community of Latin Ameri- can and Caribbean States (CELAC), Amnesty International issued a call last Wednesday for the Obama administration to \"end its human rights hypocrisy\" by the much-unfulfilled promise to close the base as a detention centre for political prisoners without a court trial. Amnesty rebuked the US president for dishonouring his own expressed commitment of five years ago, on January 22, 2009, to issue an \"executive order\" for the closure of Guantanamo as a detention centre and arrange for court trials in the USA for prisoners, declaring in a media statement from London, England: \"Five years later, this promise of change has become a human rights failure that threatens to haunt President Obama's legacy, just as it has his predecessor's (former president George W Bush), according to Erika Guevara Rosas, direc- tor of Amnesty International's Americas Programme. After a dozen years in detention since the first of hundreds of political prisoners were brought to Guantanamo\u2014\"strapped down in planes like cargo\", said Amnesty\u2014more than 150 men are still there, most of them without charge or trial, with a few subjected to trial \"under a military commission system that does not meet international fair trial standards\u2026\". Last year, Cuba, which has been protesting since its 1959 revolution the US military presence at Guantanamo (which is part of Cuban territory), reminded a meeting of the UN Human Rights Council that the torture of political prisoners at the naval base has been internationally condemned. The continuing US military occupation of Guantanamo and its misuse as a detention centre for political prisoners without legitimate court trials is expected to surface among issues to be addressed during this week's two-day CELAC meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday in Havana. Prior to the summit of heads of state and govern- ment, a two-day regional forum comprising foreign ministers and national experts from various sectors is scheduled, the first of which was to begin yesterday. Caribbean Community (Caricom) Secretary General Irwin LaRocque, who will be among participants, said in our brief telephone conversation that he expects \"a significant presence\" from the 15-member community for the CELAC summit. He pointed out the Caribbean region was actively involved from the inception in the cre- ation of the hemispheric body. Among the distinguished, special guests to be greeted by Cuban President Raoul Castro will be UN Secretary General Ban Ki Moon and the Secretary General of the Organisation of American States (OAS), Jose Miguel Insulza. Established in 2011 in Caracas as an initiative of the now late president of Venezuela Hugo Chavez, CELAC has defined itself as \"a counterpart of the OAS\". It held its first formal summit in 2013 in Santiago, Chile, the outgoing chair, now to be succeeded by Cuba. A distinguishing feature of CELAC from the OAS is both the USA and Canada have not been considered for membership at the time of conception of its formation. The CELAC summit in Ha- vana will mark the first ever official visit by an OAS secre- tary general to Cuba which, under US pressures follow- ing the Fidel Castro-led revo- lution of 1959, had been excluded from membership\u2014 a position the Caribbean island state has since showed no interest in regaining. Cuba's deputy Foreign Minister, Abelardo Moreno, in briefing the media on the CELAC summit, said he was optimistic it would \"yield very positive results for Latin America and the Carib- bean\", consistent with shared objectives in the strengthen- ing of co-operation for deep- ening integration. Meanwhile, Trinidad and Tobago was designated as \"Guest Country of Honour\" for this year's \"Cubadisco Music Festival\", which takes place in Havana from May 17-25. Since the Prime Minister of T&T normally shoulders lead responsibility for crime and security among Caricom Heads of Government, it is to be assumed that there will be updates in the agenda folder being prepared in connection with Prime Minister Persad-Bissessar's journey to Montego Bay. DNA carries all genetic instructions for the human body and almost all humans have the same genes arranged in the same order, with more than 99.5 percent of their DNA sequence in common. But it is the few differences in the base pairs \u2014 somewhere around 4 to 5 million of them \u2014 that make us unique, and can help uncover your family history and ethnic origins. Thanks to the scientific discoveries historically made this month, and continued developments in the study of DNA, it\u2019s now increasingly accessible to discover more about your ethnic origins and even connect with relatives through consumer DNA testing. Barry Starr, director of scientific communications at Ancestry, the global leader in family history and consumer genomics, answers some of the top questions about DNA tests: Will I have different DNA results than my sibling? Yes, almost certainly. You get about 50 percent of your DNA from your mom and 50 percent from your dad. But you and your siblings did not inherit the same 50 percent from each parent, so you are both going to receive different \u2018bits\u2019 of DNA from each parent (unless you\u2019re an identical twin). It\u2019s why siblings\u2019 looks and personalities can vary. If you\u2019re genetic siblings, you\u2019ll match in a DNA network as being a very close family connection, but your ethnicity estimates are likely to differ. How come my DNA results differ from what my family has told me? Even family historians, with lots of stories, photos and extensive family trees going back centuries, can be surprised by a DNA test. This is because DNA tests can uncover insights from hundreds to over 1,000 years ago that aren\u2019t in historical records \u2014 things you might never have known otherwise. Who owns my DNA and data after I\u2019ve taken a test? With AncestryDNA, you always maintain ownership and control over your own data and there are technical, administrative, and physical safeguards in place to protect personal information. For example, customers\u2019 personal data is encrypted and segmented to separate, dedicated access-controlled storage platforms, and no common identifiers are stored with any genetic data. Ancestry does not share any personal or DNA data with insurers, employers, or third-party marketers. How can my DNA results change over time? Genomics is advancing rapidly, and improvements in science and the methodology of DNA analysis can give more precise results. Your DNA doesn\u2019t change but the science behind interpreting it does, and results may be updated as the analysis becomes more accurate. ", "DATE": "Feb 20, 2014 ", "CONTENT": " I was on my way to work the other day, when I stopped by my neighborhood auto parts store to purchase a phone card. Can I have a Digicel card for 20 (twen-tee) please I asked the counter attendant. I would have said may, but I did not want to seem too formal; somehow many here always get offended when I speak correctly, so I try to tone it down (shakes head as I think about it). I should have used it here though, for this individual was different. There is hope yet! Sure, of course, he responded and walked over to the machine to get the card. Upon noticing that I was carrying a couple of books in hand, he asked, what are you studying I responded, Actually, Im a teacher. What subject English. He blurted out, Oh my! So you have like 1.6 billion people throughout Trinidad and Tobago to teach Standard English! I started laughing, as did a male friend of his who was in the store at the time. I think testosterone is overvalued in this country, he continued. A lot of men come in here and they act all macho and I cant even understand what it is theyre saying sometimes; for instance, umgimmeh ah At this point, he ruffled the rest of his words. Sometimes, they dont even know the name of the part that they came in here for. Why is it that men feel that speaking Standard English is a bad thing, and that in order to be a man-man they must speak badly It felt as if he was on a tirade, so annoyed was he by the poor English of many. He continued, Im sure this will come as no surprise to you, but you are not tall, white, blonde, etc., but when you open your mouth and you speak, its like, oh my goodness! At this point, he begins to playfully move around the store in an excited manner, moving his hands about as if to say, oh my God, Im so impressed; Im blown away! He went on, Perhaps you can lead a group of students on a walkabout throughout Port-of-Spain, take them to the different businesses so that they can see how successful people speak; perhaps you and I can collaborate on this. You see, people dont realise that speaking well actually increases your stature in this life The poor thing! I feel his pain, I really do. Like it does me, the poor English of many here sears his soul. But what I find interesting about this conversation are his statements on most men here and their belief that speaking Standard English somehow makes them less male. Why do some men hold this belief I believe it goes back to the following popular Mother Goose nursery rhyme for children, What are Little Boys Made of. The rhyme is posted on rhymes.org.uk: What are little boys made of Snips and snails, and puppy dog tails, That's what little boys are made of. What are little girls made of Sugar and spice, and everything nice, That's what little girls are made of. In other words, some females tend to be cultured, well-poised, dainty, well-mannered, soft-spoken and well-spoken. Some boys, on the other hand, are rough, rugged and ill-behaved; and given that speaking Standard English is associated with a cultured, well-bred and well-spoken individual (and rightfully so),some boys tend to shy away from it. This is particularly so in the black community, which is what I believe the attendant meant to get at when he made the point that I am not tall, white, blonde, etc. (his statement may be extended to the larger black community). But that is not so. Speaking well is an attribute of the cultured, the educated, the well-bred, the well-mannered (nothing is wrong with dialect when used appropriately). It is not a girl thing. Another influence on some males here that makes their situation all the more unique is the fact that there seems to be a tacit national agreement that speaking bad English is a Trini ting. A refrain my mother used to say a lot (and actually, still does) when I was growing up will help me to delineate my point. It went something like this and was often used to refer to people with questionable moralities, who attempted to impose those moralities on herself, my sister or me: they does feel everybodys the same eh! Perhaps this is why so many speak badly here and are comfortable with it, because they feel that everyones the same way. In fact, I am convinced that this is the case given the conversation between a taxi driver and a fellow passenger the other day as I was on my way home. Either the driver or passenger (I forget), was relating his experience of having to curse out someone at a ministry here to get something done. According to this individual, when he asked the clerk why is it he only get through after yelling and gettin on, the clerk responded, oh gosh, yuh know daz how Trini does get on. I may safely assume that that is how many think, too, in regards to speaking badly is ah Trini ting. Why else would they walk into a place of business and speak any old how and think it ok But it is not OK. Speaking badly is not a Trini ting. There are some Trinidadians who speak well, who speak Standard English. Speaking badly is a characteristic, often times, of the uneducated and the ill-bred; speaking well is a characteristic, often times, of the educated and the well-bred. The attendant in the auto parts store is correct. From the moment a person begins to speak, it is evident that persons stature in this life, and moreover, that persons stature may either increase or not; it is evident his or her academic background and the environment out of which he or she comes. So if a person opens their mouth and begins speaking badly, immediately, the person to whom he or she is speaking will infer that he or she is not well-educated, and quite possibly, comes from the lower classes (there are some in the lower classes who defy the norm, who understand the importance of speech, of presentation, so that my words are not misconstrued). And the person will treat you accordingly. If this individual is speaking to a potential employer, it is very likely that he or she will not be hired because the potential employer would worry that this person would be a bad representation of and a bad reflection on the company understandably so. And if a person opens their mouth and begins to speak well, immediately, the person to whom he or she is speaking will infer that he or she is well-educated, and quite possibly, comes from the middle or wealthier classes (the person may not even be from the middle or wealthier classes). And, again, the person will treat you accordingly. If this individual is speaking to a potential employer, it is very likely that he or she will be hired because the potential employer would feel confident that the individual would be a good representation of and a good reflection on the company understandably so. So men, there really is no harm in speaking well. The educated and truly respected in the country will tell you so, and laud you for it. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/in-the-name-of-peace/article_c72979a0-62c2-57fc-9256-61177eb90a96.html", "TITLE": " In the name of peace ", "DATE": "Dec 1, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " Yesterday, as we in this part of the world celebrated Emancipation Day, across the Atlantic hundreds of thousands of people were fleeing their homes amid a new onslaught of violence in Syria. As we look on helplessly, we are reminded of just how dangerous the world is and why we need to cherish and protect every freedom that we have. Like others before them, the people of Syria have discovered that the world does not come running to help, unless it perceives a threat to its own interest. This is the dilemma that faces international diplomacy when a government turns the forces of State might against its own citizens: political self-interest versus humanitarian interest. In 1983 Trinidad and Tobago faced this question when the Maurice Bishop-led People's Revolutionary Government of Grenada imploded. How do we assist And on what terms The issue was settled with the military intervention of the United States which triggered a major controversy over national sovereignty, Caricom as a regional force, and the humanitarian responsibilities of neighbours. Today, the dilemma facing international diplomacy involves Syria where the confrontation between the government of Bashar al-Assad and anti-government forces has escalated to the level of civil war with fatal and catastrophic consequences for the country and its people. According to the Red Cross, over 17,000 people have been killed since March last year. Collateral damage in terms of property, human hardship and industrial and economic collapse is incalculable As in the case of the other uprisings of the Arab Spring, the Syria crisis was sparked by a people's hope for change, only to be met with the full fire-power of an authoritarian regime that refuses to be challenged. While the world watched, the al-Assad regime dug in its heels and issued the order for a full military response, intent on avoiding the fate of Mubarak in Egypt and Gadaffi in Libya. Yesterday, in the country's largest city, Aleppo, military planes were said to be strafing civilians on the streets as hundreds of thousands packed their bundles and fled the city with their lives. What irony that such open bloodshed could be taking place on the same planet where just across the English Channel, the zenith of human excellence is being celebrated. How ironic, too, that the very superpowers that agree to ascribe to the highest values of the Olympic Games cannot rise above narrow self-interest to find common ground for a solution to the Syrian crisis. As in Libya, the war between the government and people of Syria is now a fight to the finish. Both sides are committed to battling to the end. Especially for the civilian forces, there can be no turning back. As a country that has provided succour for generations of Syrians who have found a home here, we can add our voices in support of an inventive international response to bringing peace to Syria. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/fundamental-dignity-for-all/article_1939b186-ab97-55e2-bee1-c59f921836ef.html", "TITLE": " Fundamental dignity for all ", "DATE": "Feb 20, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "I write to state that my main intent at the National Consultation on Constitutional Reform on Monday 10th February at UWI SPEC was to bring philosophical perspective to views that were being expressed on the floor and to strike a blow against unfair discrimination and hateful expressions of any kind. The tone of our public dialogue at present on the reform of our nation's Constitution, the fundamental document that governs how we live together in this society, should be civil, respectful and exemplify our national watchword: tolerance. We must all be able to live together on these islands in harmony after this process. The media also have a critical role to play in achieving this objective and setting a compassionate tone and accurate measure. Attaching as captions such expressions that I did not use like \"gay rights\" and \"sexual rights\" served to create some confusion in the minds of readers and to detract from the main human rights gist of the presentation. Human rights are entitlements which encompass the full range of human diversity and are based on the inherent human dignity of each and every human person and form the basis of what is called the Bill of Rights as integral to modern liberal constitutions. Constitutions are regarded as fundamental law and place persons at the heart of what a nation and its development is all about. A bill of rights recognises the inherent dignity of human beings and the rights and freedoms emerging from that dignity simply by the fact of their being human. It contains entitlements with respect to persons and protects persons from encroachments from the State and from fellow citizens. In a modern democracy and especially in a multicultural society such as Trinidad and Tobago, this provision helps to manage various and ofttimes conflicting interests, setting fundamental boundaries and rules of fair play. In the Bill of Rights as obtains in our Republican Constitution of 1976 there are fundamental inalienable rights set out at Section 4 of which marriage is not regarded as a fundamental inalienable right. The term \"fundamental inalienable right\" is defined as one which a person has or to which he/she is entitled simply because of their personhood and humanity. Although my overall approach is non-discrimination for persons on the grounds of sexual orientation, this does not obligate the State to same-sex marriage in the future. In the context of the discussion I also drew on a principle of jurisprudence which ensures that the rights of a minority not suffer under the will of the majority. Such a principle of protecting minority rights and the moral perspectives secured by constitutional laws make for sober and responsible judgment on matters affecting those citizens who may suffer the indignity of discrimination. The context of the discussion that took place at UWI SPEC was a public forum by the Ministry of Legal Affairs National Consultation on Constitutional Reform. I was commenting on Chapters Two and Three which dealt with \"Rewording the Preamble\" and \"Fundamental Rights and Freedoms\" respectively. I commented on four distinct areas, all of which I considered critically important. The first was on the wording under paragraph 37 on the \"languaging\"/wording of gender terms; second, on the inclusion of the environment; third, on the recognition of God, where I supported the idea that recognition of God should be indicated by mention of God's name but also where I specifically defended the rights of atheists who should in no way be disadvantaged or prejudiced by their belief or lack of belief; and finally on part \"b\" of page 13 which reads \"the issue of sexual orientation and human rights should be made the subject of further national discussion and public education\". What does the word mean In its broadest sense it means to be in a state of wholeness as opposed to being fragmented. The word is derived from a Latin word meaning entire or untouched. From integer there are the various derivatives of integral, integrate, integrative and of course disintegrate and disintegration. In human affairs the word integrity is accepted to mean essentially an uncompromising adherence to a code of moral or other human values, such as absolute sincerity, honesty and candour. Many consider any deceit, deception or dishonesty to be hypocrisy and the opposite of integrity. Now why should the behaviours of integrity and hypocrisy be important in human affairs Undoubtedly they are the highs and lows of human behaviour. Integrity is an expression of an acceptance of a behaviour of what is in the best interest of the common good of the group. Hypocrisy is placing self interest before collective interests of the group, even as an individual may be aware of collective benefit. The important thing to be understood about integrity is absolute adherence to some accepted code in an area of human activity. Moral codes abound in human societies, many of them originating from early religions and rulers, becoming codified in time as societies grow. Philosophically, for obvious reasons however, there are comparatively few values that one can accept as being universal. Now, what is the relevance of integrity to life in Trinidad and Tobago Of vital importance. If one seeks legal help in a matter one expects the attorney to act in your interests. Or if one buys a house, car or product, one expects the seller to be honest and there are many accepted codes. Further there is the extensive law that we have inherited as well as the law that has been passed by our Parliament that attempts to regulate general behavior in the interest of the general good for citizens. But integrity in public life is of vital importance because history has shown us that ruling classes or individuals in all societies have always more often than not put their interests above those of the general public, frequently causing considerable distress or damage of the fabric of society. We have on our books the integrity in Public Life Act 2000 replacing the earlier 1987 legislation. And while there seems to be some preoccupation with the declaration of assets little concern seems to be applied to the Code of Conduct. Moreover some of our legislators seem to have little understanding of the role of the Integrity Commission. One is reported in Hansard to have stated that the Commission was a Superior Court of Record, while another stated that a principle of natural justice was that the accuser had to prove the accusation (both were attorneys at law), both being wrong. Now there is a flurry of activity. Government claims that the existing Act is defective and proposes a number of amendments. Obviously everyone will agree that failure to declare assets in accordance with the Act is wrong and that the Commission, being the recipient of the declarations must treat all equally and be seen to do so, and take action against all who have failed to meet the requirements of the law, including the Prevention of Corruption Act. But what about complaints from the public Surely breaches of the Code of Conduct and complaints by citizens are an entirely different kettle of fish. In the Act the Commission may investigate any perceived breach on its own initiative, or, a citizen may make a written signed complaint if he/she believes that there has been a breach. In cases of breaches of the Code of Conduct it is not a matter of a \"criminal\" offence and if the Commission accepts that there has been a breach all that is required of it is that it is reported to the appropriate House of Parliament. It is then up to that House to take what action it deems necessary. In cases of complaints made it must be noted that mischievous and misleading complaints attract a serious penalty. Thus I was much surprised to learn in the recent debate that in two recent years there were only nine complaints, including two from me involving what I considered serious breaches of the Code of Conduct. Why a need for change One proposed amendment would allow me to re-submit the complaints with a sworn statement! But there is larger issue that looms. In an earlier column I expressed the view that the Integrity Commission had been fatally corrupted by the Commissioners themselves. It is now over two months that the Commission collectively resigned, something that they ought to have done months before and yet there is no Commission. But who will accept appointment now Commissioners, appointed after consultation with Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition, will face the public assumption that they are merely Manning's choices. Any complaint of any conflict of interest, even if sworn, will therefore be doomed. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/in-the-time-of-wikileaks/article_f256da10-48b5-5b7d-9fb1-138da9dbbc24.html", "TITLE": " In the time of WikiLeaks ", "DATE": "Dec 21, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " In light of ongoing developments related to the release of diplomatic cables by WikiLeaks, and the publication of information contained in those cables by mainstream news organisations, the UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Opinion and Expression and the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) Special Rapporteur for Freedom of Expression see fit to recall a number of international legal principles. The rapporteurs call upon states and other relevant actors to keep these principles in mind when responding to the aforementioned developments. 1. The right to access information held by public authorities is a fundamental human right subject to a strict regime of exceptions. The right to access to information protects the right of every person to access public information and to know what governments are doing on their behalf. It is a right that has received particular attention from the international community, given its importance to the consolidation, functioning and preservation of democratic regimes. Without the protection of this right, it is impossible for citizens to know the truth, demand accountability and fully exercise their right to political participation. National authorities should take active steps to ensure the principle of maximum transparency, address the culture of secrecy that still prevails in many countries and increase the amount of information subject to routine disclosure. 2. At the same time, the right of access to information should be subject to a narrowly tailored system of exceptions to protect overriding public and private interests such as national security and the rights and security of other persons. Secrecy laws should define national security precisely and indicate clearly the criteria which should be used in determining whether or not information can be declared secret. Exceptions to access to information on national security or other grounds should apply only where there is a risk of substantial harm to the protected interest and where that harm is greater than the overall public interest in having access to the information. In accordance with international standards, information regarding human rights violations should not be considered secret or classified. 3. Public authorities and their staff bear sole responsibility for protecting the confidentiality of legitimately classified information under their control. Other individuals, including journalists, media workers and civil society representatives, who receive and disseminate classified information because they believe it is in the public interest, should not be subject to liability unless they committed fraud or another crime to obtain the information. In addition, government \"whistleblowers\" releasing information on violations of the law, on wrongdoing by public bodies, on a serious threat to health, safety or the environment, or on a breach of human rights or humanitarian law should be protected against legal, administrative or employment-related sanctions if they act in good faith. Any attempt to impose subsequent liability on those who disseminate classified information should be grounded in previously established laws enforced by impartial and independent legal systems with full respect for due process guarantees, including the right to appeal. 4. Direct or indirect government interference in or pressure exerted upon any expression or information transmitted through any means of oral, written, artistic, visual or electronic communication must be prohibited by law when it is aimed at influencing content. Such illegitimate interference includes politically motivated legal cases brought against journalists and independent media, and blocking of websites and web domains on political grounds. Calls by public officials for illegitimate retributive action are not acceptable. 5. Filtering systems which are not end-user controlledwhether imposed by a government or commercial service providerare a form of prior censorship and cannot be justified. Corporations that provide Internet services should make an effort to ensure that they respect the rights of their clients to use the Internet without arbitrary interference. 6. Self-regulatory mechanisms for journalists have played an important role in fostering greater awareness about how to report on and address difficult and controversial subjects. Special journalistic responsibility is called for when reporting information from confidential sources that may affect valuable interests such as fundamental rights or the security of other persons. Ethical codes for journalists should therefore provide for an evaluation of the public interest in obtaining such information. Such codes can also provide useful guidance for new forms of communication and for new media organisations, which should likewise voluntarily adopt ethical best practices to ensure that the information made available is accurate, fairly presented and does not cause substantial harm to legally protected interests such as human rights. l Catalina Botero-Marino is Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression, Inter-American Commission on Human Rights. The article was co-written by Frank LaRue, UN Special Rapporteur on the Promotion and Protection of the Right to Freedom of Opinion and Expression. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/in-the-name-of-peace/article_cad54197-efda-5458-b9bf-cede76d7d4c3.html", "TITLE": " In the name of peace ", "DATE": "Dec 3, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Larry Nath Larry Nath Yesterday, as we in this part of the world celebrated Emancipation Day, across the Atlantic hundreds of thousands of people were fleeing their homes amid a new onslaught of violence in Syria. As we look on helplessly, we are reminded of just how dangerous the world is and why we need to cherish and protect every freedom that we have. Like others before them, the people of Syria have discovered that the world does not come running to help, unless it perceives a threat to its own interest. This is the dilemma that faces international diplomacy when a government turns the forces of State might against its own citizens: political self-interest versus humanitarian interest. In 1983 Trinidad and Tobago faced this question when the Maurice Bishop-led People's Revolutionary Government of Grenada imploded. How do we assist And on what terms The issue was settled with the military intervention of the United States which triggered a major controversy over national sovereignty, Caricom as a regional force, and the humanitarian responsibilities of neighbours. Today, the dilemma facing international diplomacy involves Syria where the confrontation between the government of Bashar al-Assad and anti-government forces has escalated to the level of civil war with fatal and catastrophic consequences for the country and its people. According to the Red Cross, over 17,000 people have been killed since March last year. Collateral damage in terms of property, human hardship and industrial and economic collapse is incalculable As in the case of the other uprisings of the Arab Spring, the Syria crisis was sparked by a people's hope for change, only to be met with the full fire-power of an authoritarian regime that refuses to be challenged. While the world watched, the al-Assad regime dug in its heels and issued the order for a full military response, intent on avoiding the fate of Mubarak in Egypt and Gadaffi in Libya. Yesterday, in the country's largest city, Aleppo, military planes were said to be strafing civilians on the streets as hundreds of thousands packed their bundles and fled the city with their lives. What irony that such open bloodshed could be taking place on the same planet where just across the English Channel, the zenith of human excellence is being celebrated. How ironic, too, that the very superpowers that agree to ascribe to the highest values of the Olympic Games cannot rise above narrow self-interest to find common ground for a solution to the Syrian crisis. As in Libya, the war between the government and people of Syria is now a fight to the finish. Both sides are committed to battling to the end. Especially for the civilian forces, there can be no turning back. As a country that has provided succour for generations of Syrians who have found a home here, we can add our voices in support of an inventive international response to bringing peace to Syria. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/interest-or-commitment/article_20617a1c-da1d-5ec6-93dc-af91080543bb.html", "TITLE": " Interest or commitment ", "DATE": "Mar 3, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Theres a difference between interest and commitment. When youre interested in doing something, you do it when it is convenient. When youre committed to something, you accept no excuses. My sister/friend Ali e-mailed me that quotation, and when I read it I knew immediately that it was going to be used here. The quotation even moved me to do some reflecting on the areas that may need more commitment from me and that is what some profound quotes/statements will do cause you to think carefully about topics that you may not have previously paid attention to. Alis accompanying note to the quotation suggested that we should be committed in all areas of our lives and I totally agree, and it raised the question of whether or not we are committed to God, family life. Some of us may be feeling a bit beaten, and so may have decided that we will just mosey on through life without any great conviction the key to commitment - about anything at all. Chances are the fear of failing keeps us uncommitted. And it would be timely to note here that the opposite of committed is lackadaisical, a word that many of us do not want to be described as being. The question of why we are not be as serious as we should be about personal growth which would include spiritual growth of course and personal improvement would definitely come up in this topic. The answers to that would vary of course, but if we should conclude today that we need to be more committed we should answer the question ourselves as it would relate to our relevant situations and take the next step. So what does it take for us to be committed Well, first we want to have something to be committed to of course hence the aforementioned recommendation. Having figured out the areas that need our commitment, we then work out a plan. Why we want to be committed is of utmost importance of course, because when we do not know the specifics of wanting to be commitment, at most we may just end up having an interest in whatever we thought at first we should be committed to. Whew. Yes, it sounds so complicated, but it really is not. Allow me to use myself as an example - I have had some fantastic ideas over the years if I do say so myself. If ideas alone could make one rich, I would have been a millionaire at the very least. But I only really pursued the things that I was totally committed to, and those were the things that I have had some success in. Take for instance my writing; I would write morning, noon and night if I have to. So I would like to recommend here that when something has our commitment, which is more than interest, we will be successful. Dont be too angry with yourself if you find that you were not successful at some things then. Try to measure your level of commitment to that particular thing that you thought you wanted to be successful in. Did you go the extra mile Did you lose sleep over that project or plan See it becomes clearer when you ask the questions and take enough time to answer them. Some relevant questions would be Am I committed to my God; my marriage; my relationships with my family and others; my work; making my home a home; changing for better; my health? I think that a lot of us give lip service to the word commitment, and I dont mind being corrected if I am wrong but this is true especially in the areas of romantic relationships. Interesting how I always seem to get there, yes But that is probably because I get so many questions about relationships and probably because I am committed to helping others solve their relationship issues. Ah well. Have you ever felt that being committed takes a lot from you as an individual Well, you are not alone, but there is nothing wrong in wanting to give whatever it is that you want to give your 100 per cent to nothing at all wrong with that. The results are usually well worth all the efforts that we put into getting things done; making things happen; securing the best as much as is humanly possible. So lets get more committed and stay so. Today, I am committed to staying committed in all that I have to do. So lets walk on water for little faith prays, growing faith panics, and seasoned faith walks on water. Much love. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/where-the-state-continues-to-fail-its-people/article_b7347a95-dde8-5541-8832-3b91f01948fe.html", "TITLE": " Where the State continues to fail its people ", "DATE": "Aug 16, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "As the world becomes increasingly globalised, coalescing border, communication, cultures and people, it becomes necessary as a nation to stay relevant to the global market. One of the main ways it can do so is through the management of its human resource base. Unfortunately, it seems our priorities lie elsewhere. Instead of ensuring its citizens have the best possible chance of competing on a global scale, our State continues to be more interested in obscure \u201cinitiatives\u201d that do not serve the best interests of its people. An individual born in, say, the United States is almost guaranteed a better prospective future than someone born in Trinidad and Tobago, just as someone born in Trinidad and Tobago would have a better prospect than one born in certain parts of the Middle East. It is undeniable that not everyone is born into the same socio-economic context. Race, class, ethnicity, and nationality make the playing field uneven. It is therefore not just a matter of equality, but also of equity. And it is the state which has the duty of reconciling the two. It is morally obligated to ensuring a nation's human resource has equal access to socio-economic development which can level the playing field. Programmes such as a multi-thousand boat cruise that only has the potential to increase tourism and therefore not grounded in any empirical research does not serve the interests of the people. It is a global phenomenon that politicians are generally perceived as self-serving, and our political intelligentsia is no different. Until they continue to serve the interests of the people by being truly committed to diversification in matters of education and the economy, our nation-state will fall behind the thrust to globalisation. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ps-no-action-taken-against-ex-chairman/article_7147d0a9-3285-595b-ade7-80069ebdb567.html", "TITLE": " PS: No action taken against ex-chairman ", "DATE": "Jan 9, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "NO disciplinary action has been taken against Ramchand Rampersad over allegations of a conflict of interest during his tenure as chairman of Government Human Resources Services Co Ltd (GHRS), which were exclusively reported by the Express, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Public Administration Gillian Macintyre has said. Macintyre made the statement yesterday, as the GHRS appeared before the Joint Select Committee (JSC) (Group Two) of the Parliament. The meeting was held at the J Hamilton Maurice Room. The JSC was chaired by Independent Senator Dr Victor Wheeler. In July 2012, the Express exclusively reported on Rampersad's alleged conflict of interest as chairman of GHRS. Rampersad's private company, Perfect World Human Resources and Management Services, is said to have played a role in short-listing prospective candidates for the chief executive officer's job at National Flour Mills (NFM). Rampersad's private business was incorporated in January 2012, nearly six months after he was made chairman of GHRS. Wheeler asked Macintyre what came out of this situation. Wheeler: In 2012, there were allegations of misconduct involving a senior member of the company's board and this was reported in the press, and the allegations concerned the existence of conflicts of interest regarding transactions that involved the said board member and his private firm. Are you aware if these allegations were substantiated Macintyre: The matter was referred to the Ministry of Finance for them to undertake an audit. We have not received the report on the audit as yet. ATTENTION TO DETAIL: \"Reclining Nude\" by Karen De Verteuil. Artist Karen De Verteuil doesn't take for granted her right to self-expression. The representation of the nude human body in her latest collection is an example of the artist's freedom when it comes to her expressions on canvas. De Verteuil said when it comes to depicting the human figure she is more in sync with what she loves best about her career as an artist. \"If a lot of artists are true to themselves, they will paint what they want to paint instead of painting what they think will be saleable. I draw what I want to draw and paint what I want to paint. I try to be honest with myself. Some of my works are nude, but it's what I love to do. I have a passion for drawing the human anatomy,\" De Verteuil said. The artist believes that one of the hardest things to draw is the human form. She believes one of the main focuses of the serious artist is the study of the human figure. She said, \"It's very interesting; I like to get the body language. It's very important to get the essence of the figure I'm working on. I've always loved to create artwork that depicts people,\" she said. The artist recently showed 40 of her latest works at 101 Art Gallery at Holder's Studio in Newtown. While there are various works depicting a number of subjects, De Verteuil's focus has little to do with themes and more to do with structure. Virtually self-taught, De Verteuil mainly works in oils. Though her work is representational, she is mainly concerned with shape, negative space and line. The subject being of less importance than the juxtaposition of planes and colour, she focuses on the near and seeks to explain her delight in the curve of a branch, the crook of an arm or the angle of a neck. She added, \"Theme doesn't matter to me. I will do any theme, but it's the details that count. I try not to be too realistic, and I tend to keep things simple and clean,\" she said. While De Verteuil is happy with her latest works, she said she is constantly improving her skills and enjoys experimenting. \"I keep looking for workshops to improve, but I enjoy experimenting on my own. I like working with pastels so I want to do a lot more of that,\"she said. However, some quick checking yesterday with the Caribbean Community Secretariat in Georgetown and Caricom's Implementation Agency for Crime and Security (IMPACS),made it abundantly clear that it was neither an error nor a laughing matter. Indeed, with the dust yet to settle on thepoliticalstorm that blew across T&T last Friday in the form of a parliamentary exposure about very extensive and intrusivespying activities operated by theprevious government of ex-prime minister Patrick Manning, there camea surprising press releasethis pastMonday from the Community Secretariat. It announced the holding of a five-day training workshop which is currently occurring in Port of Spain until Friday (November 19) and involves 20 immigration officers from 11 Caricom countries, in addition toseven law enforcement officers from the Special Anti-Crime Unit of Trinidad and Tobago (SAUTT). Under normal circumstances, such a news release from the Community Secretariat would simply have been taken as notification of another work programme of IMPACS. This isthe agency originally established to serve security needs for our region's hosting of Cricket World Cup 2007. However, given the grave implications of the violations of thefundamental rights of citizens across allraces, political parties, social classes and professionsbythe spying network that alsoinvolved activities by SAUTTpersonnel,it is ironic that this state agency is involvedin theso-called \"train-the- trainer workshop'' currently underway in Port of Spain. True, arrangements for the workshop would have preceded last week's statement by Prime Minister Persad-Bissessar about the shocking illegal spying operations in which not just SAUTT was initially involved. There came the shocking exposure of even more disturbing dirty activitiesby an uncoveredSecret Intelligence Agency (SIA) that was out of control with millions of dollars and a quantity of sophisticated weapons at its disposal It may perhaps have been too late for either the Caricom Secretariat and/or the T&T government to pull the plug on the five-day \"train-the-trainer'' workshop at SAUTT's Cumuto-based training facilities. Nevertheless, it's difficult not to note an insensitivity on the part of those who have collaborated on this training project with SAUTT as core partner, as if oblivious of the negative image of this state agency facing a doubtful future. Unlike what alarming details the people of T&T and the region in general came to learn about last Friday on the SIA, they had already been alerted to the disturbing functioning of SAUTT, for instance, that the six-month old People's Partnership Government of PM Persad-Bissessar felt compelled, on the basis of controversial reports, to terminate the services of the former director of SAUTT and to significantly overhaul its operations, pending furtherdecision on its future. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/help-can-hinder-the-homeless/article_60fa390a-d855-5693-9b27-02739f7f7197.html", "TITLE": " Help can hinder the homeless ", "DATE": "Mar 25, 2009 ", "CONTENT": " Efforts to rid the city streets of the homeless have been ongoing, so it is not fair to say that the present initiative has come about simply because of the approaching Summit of the Americas although the Government has clearly concluded that another thrust is necessary, what with all the visitors who will be on hand. Most of those visitors, if not all, would hardly be put out by such sightings, disturbing though they may be, since homelessness is a feature of the modern world whether it be the result of natural or man-made convulsions or of that individual inability to cope arising from stressful conditions of which drug addiction is as much symptom as cause. By providing facilities for treatment as well as shelter, this Manning administration is attempting to address the call of both humane and unfeeling citizens who feel that \"they should put these people somewhere'' meaning, of course, out of sight and, hopefully, out of mind, the problem largely seen to be of the vagrants' own making. Facile as this conclusion is, it is nonetheless true that a major block to their rehabilitation is the addiction that life on the streets turns out to be for many, if not all. In part, this is what is behind Social Development Minister Amery Browne's call on citizens to make the streets unfriendly for homeless people. This is based on the reasoning that as long as the homeless feel they can get by on handouts from the public, they will not be moved to embrace the facilities provided since the curse of addiction is that it makes people behave against their own demonstrable interests. Still it is not certain that citizens will heed his call given both their innate kindness and the onus placed on them by every single religion practised here, to \"feed the hungry''. But they should, at least over a period of time, the better for us to chronicle whether the Government's plans for this section of the society will work to the point where not only, or even chiefly, the pavements are free of human detritus but whether these \"walking wounded'' regain some level of life quality in keeping with their essential humanity. Their fellows who insist on giving out periodic handouts, the better to meet their religious convictions, thereby salving their own consciences are, in the context of the ongoing and humane drive, being selfish even as they bask in the warmth of their own supposed generosity. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/caribbean-filmmakers-to-be-recognised-for-human-rights/article_8fec907b-2ac3-54ee-bedb-18fca6a95f10.html", "TITLE": " Caribbean filmmakers to be recognised for human rights ", "DATE": "Sep 10, 2017 ", "CONTENT": "Jeffrey Jeffrey The Trinidad and Tobago Film Festival (ttff) will once again underline the importance of film as a vehicle for raising awareness about human rights issues and advancing inclusion and social justice, with the awarding of the Amnesty International Human Rights Film Prize. Established in an effort to support the promotion of human rights in Trinidad and Tobago and the Caribbean, the Amnesty International Human Rights Prize will be awarded to a Caribbean filmmaker whose film best highlights a human rights issue. The winning film will be chosen by a three-person jury, which this year comprises Gregory Sloane-Seale, National Coordinator, Citizen Security Programme in the Ministry of National Security; Dr Gabrielle Hosein, Head of Department and lecturer, Institute for Gender and Development Studies, at The University of the West Indies, and Pamela Carmona, Regional Youth and Activism Coordinator at the, Amnesty International Americas Regional Office, in Mexico. The films in this year's competition are: Cargo - Kareem Mortimer, Bahamas Kevin owns a battered boat, but a living from fishing won't keep him afloat. Desperate, he puts his boat to another use; transporting equally desperate Haitians from the Bahamas on their way to enter the US illegally. He's taken risks before \u2014 this time he must pull off the biggest one of all. Entre 2 Rives: De Saint-Domingue \u00e0 Pointe-\u00e0-Pitre - Mariette Monpierre, Guadeloupe A chronicle of the struggle of two Dominican women, who left everything behind, including their own children, to move to Guadeloupe in hope of a better life. More than ten years later, they still fight everyday to bring their children across to their new home. Two women, two shores, one dream. Jeffrey - Yanillys Perez, Dominican Republic Twelve-year-old Jeffrey's mother wakes him not for school but to clean windshields in traffic to pay the rent, as he's done for 6 years. His older brother sings reggaet\u00f3n, and - anxious to break free of their crushing poverty - he hopes to follow suit as \u201cJeffrey the Nightmare\u201d. In addition to receiving a trophy, the winning filmmaker will also be given a cash prize of TT$5000. Annabelle Alcazar, programme director of the ttff said: \u201cFilms have the power to give voice to those most affected by injustice, and to inspire individuals and communities to stand up and speak out against injustices such as racism, sexism, LGBT discrimination, poverty, broken justice systems and other issues that impact communities and suppress the notion of democracy for all.\u201d And according Pamela Carmona at Amnesty International Americas Regional Office, in Mexico, \u201cCaribbean filmmakers have been fearless in crafting powerful stories of human struggle, sacrifice and triumph - reaching across cultures and countries, transcending language barriers to speak eloquently on the issues of human rights and social justice. As long as human rights violations exist, there will always be a need for such films, and this prize is our way of acknowledging the important work being done by filmmakers and activists in the Caribbean region.\" Amnesty International is a global movement of more than three million members, supporters and activists in over 150 countries and territories. The organisation exposes human rights violations and campaigns for their full enjoyment for everyone around the world. It is independent of Governments, political ideology, economic interest or religion, and is funded mainly by its membership and public donations. The trinidad+tobago film festival (ttff) celebrates films from and about the Caribbean and its diaspora, as well as from world cinema, through an annual festival and year-round screenings. In addition, the ttff seeks to facilitate the growth of Caribbean cinema by offering a wide-ranging industry programme and networking opportunities. The ttff is presented by Flow; given leading sponsorship by BP Trinidad and Tobago and the Ministry of Community Development, Culture and the Arts; supporting sponsorship by the Inter-American Development Bank and UN Women; and contributing sponsorship from RBC Royal Bank. It also relates to the illicit use of mobile phones slipped in behind the walls. As the then minister of justice, I recognised that with low wages the prison officers themselves were always part of the problem. When one looks for solutions, it is necessary to think outside the box and to drive the process of change irrespective of opposition from entrenched interests. Leadership is about leading to achieve the objective. One of the approaches I was pursuing up to my ministerial demise was introduction of the village concept in offender management at the Golden Grove Prison as a pilot project of the Ministry of Justice, in which there would be a gradual step away from force and lockdown within the prisons walls. Instead of locking up ten men in a concrete room with a small window like animals, it would be more productive to have them free to roam a large, confined open area in which there would be access to sporting facilities, a supercentre and industry for work. Toilets and washrooms would be available in this village. Each inmate, and in particular low-risk remandees who have not been convicted and are unable to obtain bail, would be issued a smart card which could be renewed each week with approved limits. Each inmate would be able to use the smart card to buy their own cigarettes and other allowable items on the black market listing for a fraction of the cost. There could even be fast-food outlets and, for those who no longer have relatives who care about them, prison industries such as assembling furniture and bikes imported knock-down would offer opportunities for earning income in order to recharge their smart cards. The use of telephones on the wall would allow for monitoring conversations and the obtaining of vital intelligence for interdiction of wrongdoing. In this way, we would treat with our inmates on a more humane basis. Let them sweat out their frustration playing ball rather than have them locked up like dogs in a cell. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-humane-passport-system/article_d4ed1fca-452f-53b5-8985-eb8026d7cd70.html", "TITLE": " A humane passport system ", "DATE": "Nov 13, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "swashbuckling knock of 89: Hayley Matthews swashbuckling knock of 89: Hayley Matthews The recent incident involving a Saudi Arabian diplomat provides us with lessons one of which we should not miss. Whatever may be said about Saudi Arabia at least their government does take steps to facilitate Muslims who wish to make the pilgrimage to Mecca, an important pillar of the Islamic religion. Few countries can or have interest in maintaining consular offices in all 200-odd countries of the world. In fact there are only 48 diplomatic missions based in Trinidad and Tobago, almost half of them being serviced by honorary consuls. But Saudi Arabia and Venezuela have full embassies in their countries. Normally applications for visas to travel to Saudi Arabia have to be processed in Caracas. The presence of a Saudi diplomat in Trinidad and Tobago to facilitate the granting of visas surely eases the burden on T&T pilgrims. Can we really say that our Government acts likewise We ask this in the light of the experience of some members of the family of Mark Meredith, a former writer for the Express, whose wife and daughter, now resident in New Zealand, find that they cannot acquire machine readable passports except that they travel to London. It seems that until they complete another two years residence and become eligible for New Zealand passports, they are trapped there. This situation is not unlike that faced by many citizens here. We do not of course accuse the Minister of National Security of deliberately deceiving citizens but his recent statements regarding the duration of the wait for new passports do confuse, if not mislead people. While we must accept that there may be a marked shortening of the duration of time for preparation of the document this can only be that interval between the formal interview by appointment and the issue of the document. Once again, I have drawn attention to the danger posed to countries of the Caribbean by the withdrawal of correspondent banking relations (CBRs) from regional banks by global banks in the US. As lead speaker at the opening of a legislative forum in the US House of Representatives on Capitol Hill, as part of Caribbean-American Heritage Month on June 5, I told an audience representing the US congress, the US government, diplomats, and US and Caribbean businessmen, the following: \u201cCBRs are the lifeblood of global commerce and human development. They are as vital to the world as are air and sea transportation, telecommunications, the Internet, and the fight to end communicable diseases\u201d. Without CBRs nations will not be able to pay each other for purchases of basic things, such as food and medicine, and ordinary things like buses, trucks and motor cars. Without CBRs the global financial and trading system would come to a halt, and affected countries will collapse into poverty from which recovery will be costly, both in time and money, but more importantly in human life. This grave threat has been hanging over the Caribbean now for almost half a decade, and it shows no sign of abating, despite statements to the contrary. Right now, in many parts of the Caribbean, most banks are reduced to having only one correspondent bank, and at an extremely high cost. Not only have the fees for these CBRs reached prohibitively high levels, they are taking longer periods of time to deliver services because of heightened scrutiny. Where, in the past, a cross-border transaction could take two days, it can now take as long as two weeks from our smaller, indigenous financial institutions. The cost of doing business in our region is escalating, even as we try to cope with high debt, incurred largely to recover our countries from disasters that have increased in frequency and intensity as a result of global warming and sea level rise that point like daggers at the heart of the existence of many of our island states. It is claimed \u2014 wrongfully \u2014 that Caribbean countries have weak anti-money laundering and counterterrorism financing regimes, and this is the reason global banks in the US are withdrawing CBRs. But, the two bodies with the authority to determine the quality and standing of the regimes in the Caribbean, have judged most Caribbean countries to be in compliance with their rigorous standards. Those bodies are the Financial Action Task Force and the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development Global Forum. In some sectors of financial services Caribbean legislative and enforcement machineries have been rated at a higher level of compliance than the US. Nonetheless, the Caribbean faces the real danger of being \u201cde-banked\u201d, and cut off from the world\u2019s trading and financing system, including not being able to pay for its imports from the United States\u2014the country that the region chooses as its major source market. I went on to point out that \u201cif Caribbean economies diminish, the consequences will be increased unemployment, enlarged poverty, increased crime, and the advent of economic refugees that will swell the numbers of those gathering on the US southern border\u201d. Earlier in the presentation, I had stressed that while the US suffers a trade deficit with many countries and regions of the world, it enjoys a perennial trade surplus with the 14 independent Caricom countries collectively, which increases every year. In 2015, the value of the US balance of trade surplus was US$4.1 billion; in 2016, it rose to US$4.6 billion, jumping to US$5.5 billion in 2017, and escalating further to US$7 billion in 2018. That money has provided profits for American companies and jobs for American people. I also drew attention to the reality that, since the 1990s, US official development assistance to the region has steadily declined. In 2017, a year in which the US enjoyed a $5.5-billion trade surplus with Caricom countries, the region, including Haiti, received a mere 0.9 per cent of US global allocation of official development assistance. These figures were not mentioned in complaint. Every country in the world has the right to decide to whom it provides assistance, to what extent it does so, and for what purposes. But, since the Caricom region provides the US with an escalating trade surplus every year, the US should have an interest in the economic growth and prosperity of these nations. In the final analysis, if Caribbean countries are unable to maintain a stable rate of economic growth, or if they decline, they will no longer be able to purchase goods and services from the US, and the trade surplus which the US has continuously enjoyed will shrink, and so too will the revenues and jobs that it generates in America. Therefore, there is a symbiotic and mutual interest in the US-Caribbean relationship that must be recalibrated to ensure that, as the \u201cthird border\u201d of the US, the Caribbean remains a zone of peace and a stable economic and political space. That means that the US and Caribbean countries should set \u2014 and measure their relations \u2014 in the mutuality of their interests. All issues should be discussed, including the hot button ones for the US, such as Venezuela, Nicaragua, and even the role of China in the region, but they ought not to be the single prism through which relations are evaluated. Today, most Caricom countries are stable and democratic and human rights are respected and upheld, the rights of the individual and of businesses thrive, and the rule of law is maintained. But these conditions are only maintainable in conditions of sustained development. Democracy, freedom and the rule of law are fragile plants whose growth and strength must be watered and fed by the nutrients of economic development. The US cannot choose to move out of the neighbourhood any more than can Caribbean countries opt to relocate elsewhere. They each, therefore, have an obligation to recognise their mutuality of interests and to act on it. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/in-the-name-of-peace/article_eab5a05c-39ba-51db-9239-9f574310f27d.html", "TITLE": " In the name of peace ", "DATE": "Dec 2, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "committed: Niala Persad Poliah committed: Niala Persad Poliah Yesterday, as we in this part of the world celebrated Emancipation Day, across the Atlantic hundreds of thousands of people were fleeing their homes amid a new onslaught of violence in Syria. As we look on helplessly, we are reminded of just how dangerous the world is and why we need to cherish and protect every freedom that we have. Like others before them, the people of Syria have discovered that the world does not come running to help, unless it perceives a threat to its own interest. This is the dilemma that faces international diplomacy when a government turns the forces of State might against its own citizens: political self-interest versus humanitarian interest. In 1983 Trinidad and Tobago faced this question when the Maurice Bishop-led People's Revolutionary Government of Grenada imploded. How do we assist And on what terms The issue was settled with the military intervention of the United States which triggered a major controversy over national sovereignty, Caricom as a regional force, and the humanitarian responsibilities of neighbours. Today, the dilemma facing international diplomacy involves Syria where the confrontation between the government of Bashar al-Assad and anti-government forces has escalated to the level of civil war with fatal and catastrophic consequences for the country and its people. According to the Red Cross, over 17,000 people have been killed since March last year. Collateral damage in terms of property, human hardship and industrial and economic collapse is incalculable As in the case of the other uprisings of the Arab Spring, the Syria crisis was sparked by a people's hope for change, only to be met with the full fire-power of an authoritarian regime that refuses to be challenged. While the world watched, the al-Assad regime dug in its heels and issued the order for a full military response, intent on avoiding the fate of Mubarak in Egypt and Gadaffi in Libya. Yesterday, in the country's largest city, Aleppo, military planes were said to be strafing civilians on the streets as hundreds of thousands packed their bundles and fled the city with their lives. What irony that such open bloodshed could be taking place on the same planet where just across the English Channel, the zenith of human excellence is being celebrated. How ironic, too, that the very superpowers that agree to ascribe to the highest values of the Olympic Games cannot rise above narrow self-interest to find common ground for a solution to the Syrian crisis. As in Libya, the war between the government and people of Syria is now a fight to the finish. Both sides are committed to battling to the end. Especially for the civilian forces, there can be no turning back. As a country that has provided succour for generations of Syrians who have found a home here, we can add our voices in support of an inventive international response to bringing peace to Syria. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/hanging-on-to-human-rights/article_f74652e2-170c-5c2c-9b07-aa021642508d.html", "TITLE": " Hanging on to human rights ", "DATE": "Sep 1, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "These comments are offered by someone who has been studying, teaching and practicing the international system of human rights for several years. The general contention is that there is a low level of awareness and understanding of this universal set of norms and standards to which Trinidad and Tobago has signed on and has become a contracting party. We often ignore the fact that the basic human rights provisions have not found their way into our Constitution \"out of the blue\", but are inspired by and derived from the universal system of human rights. While we are all subjected to ever-increasing globalisation and complain about the negative effects in particular on the more vulnerable countries, we ignore the existence of the ever-evolving international system of human rights, set up to protect the rights of the weaker and vulnerable people of our societies. Why then the low awareness and little recognition Could it be simple ignorance, neglect, misunderstanding, information deficit It's probably all of the above. The widespread call for the resumption of hanging in light of heinous crimes and gruesome murders is well understood. What is not understood is the call by some to withdraw T&T from international human rights bodies and treaties, in order to resume hanging. Nowhere in the international human rights system, at least in those instruments that Trinidad and Tobago has ratified, is there a provision that simply outlaws capital punishment altogether. Reference is made to one of the two basic pillars of the international human rights system which was ratified by T&T in 1978, i.e. the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It speaks specifically to the question of capital punishment. While it stipulates in Article Six, the inherent right to life for every human being, it allows for exceptions, notably for states which have not abolished the death penalty. They \"may impose it only for the most serious crimes, in accordance with the law in force and in accordance with a final judgment rendered by a competent court\". Thus, there is no need to withdraw from the Covenant and deprive citizens of the protection of other basic civil and political rights. What has been added in our own jurisdiction is the condition that capital punishment must be carried out within a certain timeframe, a namely maximum five years from the date of the first sentence to the date of the final judgment. The Covenant give states the opportunity to sign on to two optional protocols. One gives people the right to directly appeal to the UN Human Rights Committee. The other entails a commitment of signatory states to abolish the death penalty altogether. Trinidad and Tobago withdrew from the first optional protocol under the previous UNC administration, and with regard to the second optional protocol, it has never signed on to it, precisely because this protocol is \"optional\" and entails the commitment to abolish the death penalty. The Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, like all the other basic human rights instruments, imposes on states the obligation to submit periodic reports to the respective UN Human Rights bodies/committees, composed of independent human rights experts. Such reports should be presented every three to five years and they should indicate progress made and challenges encountered by the states in implementing at the national level the various human rights treaties. These reports are examined by the experts in concert with the national representatives, not to sanction possible shortcomings, but to provide advice and assistance. In the case of Trinidad and Tobago, it must be noted that this country is lagging far behind in fulfilling its reporting obligations. The last time T&T presented a report to the UN Human Rights Committee was 1999. Why then the question is asked again is there little recognition and awareness of the international human rights system in T&T It is admitted that, overall, the country's human rights record is relatively good. No gross human rights violations have taken place since independence. This may explain in part the absence of any high interest in international human rights issues, except now in the debate on capital punishment and its implications. However, there is need for promotion and wider appreciation of the international human rights system. Promoting international human rights is often a question of educational priorities. Nowhere in our high school system is there place and space for human rights teaching. Worse yet, nowhere in our law school and on the campus of UWI is there any structured teaching or research conducted on the international system of human rights and its application in T&T; so that generations of lawyers do not have the necessary knowledge and understanding of this particular branch of international law. This is also a call to the media to heighten their interest and coverage of noteworthy information relating to the international human rights system. To conclude by giving just one example: The UN Human Rights Council has set up a human rights probe into the deadly raid by Israel on a Gaza-bound Turkish flotilla carrying food and other relief articles. The probe is conducted by a panel of three human rights experts, headed by Karl Hudson-Phillips. The international media carried this news item, but no mention was made in the local media. Karl and his team are right now in the Middle East for further investigations. This international human rights assignment would also explain his absence at the national awards ceremony at Queen's Hall on Independence Day! Dr Hans Geiser is former head of UN/UNDP. He is Hon.
